I'm running into trouble with resource limitations on my data processing pipeline.
Currently running a processing pipeline on computer with 64GB of RAM. Once you add in chunking / embedding processes while also hosting a qdrant image with a large amount of vectors the resource usage really starts to add up.
I've tried to set everything to 'on disk'. Despite this the RAM still seems to increase. I am then experiencing various errors where things cannot process which appear to be related to limited resource availbility.

So far I have set
- Dense vector to disk: True
- Payload to disk: True
- HNSW index to disk: True
- Sparse vectors: Can sparse vectors be stored on disk rather than RAM? It's not clear what they are by default.

Can anyone advise on the above or any other tips on how to manage data creation / upload pipelines while keeping resource usage low.
Scale of the dataset is in the order of (10M to 100M+ dense and sparse vectors). Can qdrant be set to an 'upload only' mode during processing?

Kind regards
Got it, thanks

Hi there, unfortunately we dont support scaling down of clusters, as block storage can only be scaled up. The best route forward would be to take snapshots of the collections, create a new cluster of your desired size and then restore the collections to the new cluster. After the collections have been moved you can delete the old cluster. Here are some docs to help you along! 

https://qdrant.tech/documentation/concepts/snapshots/

content: perfect, thnx
collection snapshot

I think it should work in both cases, but the process would be a bit different:

If you have a *collection snapshot* taken on a single-node Qdrant setup, you should be able to simply restore it with `/collections/<new collection name on cluster setup>/snapshots/upload` or `/collections/<collection name>/snapshots/recover`. However, *only the node that you've sent `upload`/`restore` request to* would have shards. You can then replicate these shards on the other nodes in the cluster with respective request. However, if your collection in a single node setup only had one shard, you can't really "split" this shard into smaller shards.

If you have a *full storage snapshot*, then you should be able to *restart a node of the cluster with `--storage-snapshot <path to full storage snapshot>` CLI parameter*, and it will restore everything in the full storage snapshot on this node. Once again, all shards would exist on this node only, and you can replicate them through the API, but can't "split" a single shard into more smaller shards.
Hi @.bobruisk! Quick question: are you talking about collection snapshot (`/collections/<collection name>/snapshots` REST endpoint) or full storage snapshot (`/snapshots` REST endpoint)?

```
    def get_all_rows(
        self,
        collection_name: str,
        with_payload: bool | list[str] = False,
        with_vectors: bool = False,
    ) -> tuple[list[Record], PointId | None]:
        limit: int = self.get_num_entities(collection_name)

        return self.client.scroll(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            limit=limit,
            with_payload=with_payload,
            with_vectors=with_vectors,
        )

    def get_top_k_candidates(  # noqa: PLR0913
        self,
        collection_name: str,
        model_recipe: str,
        embeddings: EMBEDDINGS,
        k: int,
        filters: dict | None = None,
        with_payload: bool | list[str] = False,
        score_threshold: float | None = None,
    ) -> list[ScoredPoint]:
        return self.client.search(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            query_vector=NamedVector(name=model_recipe, vector=embeddings),
            query_filter=(
                Filter(must=[FieldCondition(key=k, match=MatchValue(value=v)) for k, v in filters.items()])
                if filters is not None
                else None
            ),
            search_params=SearchParams(exact=True),
            limit=k,
            with_payload=with_payload,
            score_threshold=score_threshold,
        )
```

what we query is like the below -

```
    def scroll_any(
        self,
        collection_name: str,
        key: str,
        values: list,
        limit: int,
        with_payload: bool | list[str] = False,
        with_vectors: bool = False,
    ) -> tuple[list[Record], PointId | None]:
        return self.client.scroll(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            scroll_filter=Filter(must=[FieldCondition(key=key, match=MatchAny(any=values))]),
            limit=limit,
            with_payload=with_payload,
            with_vectors=with_vectors,
        )

    def get_points_with_filters(
        self,
        collection_name: str,
        points: list[int],
        filters: dict,
        limit: int,
        with_payload: bool | list[str] = False,
        with_vectors: bool = False,
    ) -> tuple[list[Record], PointId | None]:
        return self.client.scroll(
            collection_name=collection_name,
            scroll_filter=Filter(
                must=[FieldCondition(key=k, match=MatchValue(value=v)) for k, v in filters.items()]
                + [HasIdCondition(has_id=points)]
            ),
            limit=limit,
            with_payload=with_payload,
```

My only conclusion (based on above tests) is that collection size somehow is in play here.  Same document in both collections -- but when it is surrounded by 70K *other* docs, my Q&A search (from langchain) is not yielding an answer -- only when it is by itself.

I  have a products table that has a lot of columns, which from these, the following ones are important for our search:

Title 1 to Title 6 (title in 6 different languages)
Brand name (in 6 different languages)
Category name (in 6 different languages)
Product attributes like size, color, etc. (in 6 different languages)
We are planning on using qdrant vector search to implement fast vector queries. But the problem is that all the data important for searching, are in different columns and I do not think (correct me if I am wrong) generating vector embeddings separately for all the columns is the best solution.

I came up with the idea of mixing the columns together and generating separate collections; and I came up with this solution because the title, the category, brand and attrs columns are essentially the same just in different langs.

Also I use the "BAAI/bge-m3" model which is a multilingual text embedding model that supports more than 100 langs.

So, in short, I created different collections for different languages, and for each collection I have a vector column containing the vector for the combined text of title, brand, color, and category in each language and when searched, because we already know which language the website is, we will search in that specific language collection.

Now, the question is, is this a valid method? What are the pros and cons of this method? I know for sure that when combined, I can not give different weights to different parts of this vector. For example one combined text of title, category, color, and brand may look like this:

"Koala patterned hoodie children blue Bubito"

or Something like:

"Striped t-shirt men navy blue Zara"

Now, user may search "blue hoodie for men", but due to the un-weighted structure of the combined vector, it will not retrieve the best results.

I may be wrong and this may be one of the best results, but please tell me more about the pros and cons of this method, and if you can, give me a better idea.

Okay. @null A few points:
1. `init_from` only works with real collection names and ignores aliases. Sadly, it isn't obvious.
2. `migrate` copied ~30k points in like 2 minutes. `init_from` copied ~300k points in the same time! So please-please-please don't remove `init_from`!
3. `migrate` validates on `vectors_count` basis. But if the original collection had some points deleted from it (so that `points_count > vectors_count`), the validation fails, even though the migration was correct. I think it's a flaw in logic and deserves fixing.
https://github.com/qdrant/qdrant-client/blob/master/qdrant_client/migrate/migrate.py#L142-L143

```
import asyncio
import time
from qdrant_client import AsyncQdrantClient
from qdrant_client.http import models
from typing import List
from sentence_transformers import SentenceTransformer
import pandas as pd
import logging
import traceback

model = SentenceTransformer("BAAI/bge-large-zh-v1.5","cuda")
client = AsyncQdrantClient("192.168.1.76", port=6335)
async def retrieve_context(index,text):
    model_context = []
    try:
        searched_results = await client.search(
            collection_name="faq_private",
            query_filter=models.Filter(
                must=[
                    models.FieldCondition(
                        key="type",
                        match=models.MatchValue(
                            value="faq",
                        ),
                    )
                ]
            ),
            timeout=600,
            search_params=models.SearchParams(exact=True),
            query_vector=text['embeddings'],
            limit=10,
        )
        for item in searched_results:
            cur_context = f"{item.payload['question']}\n{item.payload['answer']}"
            if cur_context not in model_context:
                model_context.append(cur_context)
    except Exception as e:
        traceback.print_exc()
    return (index,model_context)

async def main(data):
    tasks = [retrieve_context(index,item) for index,item in data.iterrows()]  # Create 100 tasks
    responses = await asyncio.gather(*tasks, return_exceptions=False)
    return data

if __name__ == "__main__":
    start_time = time.time()
    data = pd.read_csv("eval_embed_data.csv",index_col=0).reset_index()
    text_embedding = model.encode(data['splitted_question'].to_list(),normalize_embeddings=True)
    data['embeddings'] = text_embedding
    asyncio.run(main(data))
    end_time = time.time()
    print(f"Total time taken: {end_time - start_time:.2f} seconds")
```

>  Is there cases of MergeOptimizer merge both indexed and unindexed segments?

yeah, it is possible

Hi @null, I have a question:  For insert and delete operation and how it affects reindexing:
    * Insert: New inserted points go into plain unindexed segments. Once a segment grows beyond the threshold, the IndexingOptimizer builds an index in the background and replaces it.
    * Delete: If you delete old points, it should belong to indexed segments. And if there are many small segments, the MergeOptimizer will automatically merge old indexed segments.
* In this case, the segments that will be reindexed between insert and delete operation will not overlapped. Is my undestanding correct? Is there cases of MergeOptimizer merge both indexed and unindexed segments?
Yes, these settings can be set while creating the collection, or updated afterwards
Is this configuration not while installing the qdrant? It looks like while creating or updating the collection through programming.

There are several settings to control this, and yes, they can be updated without recreating the collection

https://qdrant.github.io/qdrant/redoc/index.html#tag/collections/operation/update_collection

Options are: 
- `vectors.<vector_name>.on_disk`
- `optimizers_config.memmap_threshold`
- `hnsw_config.on_disk`

Where can we enable that option? Whether to load to RAM or process on Premium SSD(PV/PVC).
Once we enable to use SSD, is it possible to switch back to RAM or Vice Versa?
Just put out the PR.

You have the option to keep all vectors in RAM or on-disk. The second option does memory mapping, so a fast, local disk is highly recommended. 
Note that this memory usage does not depend so much on the requests, but on the size of the collections.

Hi

1) In Qdrant container logs (idk if you are using it localy or in cloud though) you can find how much time did each request take 
2) If it exceeds timeout of 600 seconds, then it's worth checking some other parts rather than timeouts
- Do you have a payload index on `type` field?
- Why do you use `exact=True`, are you sure you want to use it? It is a brute-force search, it does not use any HNSW index
- How many points do you have in your collection? You use memmap_threshold, do you have fast disks, it is not a rare case when disks are the actual bottlenecks
3) If your system is high-load, I would consider switching to gRPC if possible
